abstract.text: The Dalitz decays η → e + e − γ and ω → π 0 e + e − have been measured in the γp → ηp and γp → ωp reactions, respectively, with the A2 tagged-photon facility at the Mainz Microtron, MAMI.

The value obtained for the slope parameter of the electromagnetic transition form factor of η, Λ −2 η = (1.97 ± 0.11tot ) GeV −2 , is in good agreement with previous measurements of the η → e + e − γ and η → µ + µ − γ decays.
The uncertainty obtained in the value of Λ −2 η is lower than in previous results based on the η → e + e − γ decay.

The value obtained for the ω slope parameter, Λ −2 ωπ 0 = (1.99 ± 0.21tot) GeV −2 , is somewhat lower than previous measurements based on ω → π 0 µ + µ − , but the results for the ω transition form factor are in better agreement with theoretical calculations, compared to earlier experiments.

body_text.text: I. INTRODUCTION

The electromagnetic (e/m) transition form factors (TFFs) of light mesons play an important role in under- * corresponding author, e-mail: prakhov@ucla.edu standing the properties of these particles as well as in lowenergy precision tests of the Standard Model (SM) and Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) [1].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In particular, these TFFs enter as contributions to the hadronic lightby-light (HLbL) scattering calculations [2,3] that are important for more accurate theoretical determinations of the anomalous magnetic moment of the muon, (g − 2) µ , within the SM [4,5].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Recently, data-driven approaches, using dispersion relations, have been proposed [2,3,6] to make a substantial and model-independent improvement to the determination of the HLbL contribution to (g−2) µ .
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The precision of the calculations used to describe the HLbL contributions to (g − 2) µ can then be tested by directly comparing theoretical predictions from these approaches for e/m TFFs of light mesons with experimental data.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The precise knowledge of TFFs for light mesons is essential for precision calculation of the decay rates of those mesons in rare dilepton modes, e + e − and µ + µ − [7,8].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: So far there are discrepancies between theoretical calculations and experimental data for these rare decays, and the Dalitz decays of the corresponding mesons in the timelike (the energy transfer larger than the momentum transfer) momentum-transfer (q) region can be used in such calculations for both the normalization of these rare decays and as a background.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The same applies to rare decays of light mesons into four leptons.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

For a structureless (pointlike) meson A, its decays into a lepton pair plus a photon or another meson, A → ℓ + ℓ − B, can be described within Quantum Electrodynamics (QED) via A → γ * B, with the virtual photon γ * decaying into the lepton pair [9].
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: QED predicts a specific strong dependence of the meson-A decay rate on the dilepton invariant mass, m ℓℓ = q.
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: A deviation from the pure QED dependence, caused by the actual electromagnetic structure of the meson A, is formally described by its e/m TFF [10].
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: The Vector-Meson-Dominance (VMD) model [11] can be used to describe the coupling of the virtual photon γ * to the meson A via an intermediate virtual vector meson V .
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: This mechanism is especially strong in the timelike momentum-transfer region, (2m ℓ ) 2 < q 2 < m 2 A , where a resonant behavior near q = m V of the virtual photon arises because the virtual vector meson is approaching the mass shell [10], or even reaching it, as for the η ′ → ℓ + ℓ − γ decay.
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: Thus, measuring TFFs of light mesons is ideally suited for testing the VMD model.
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: Experimentally, timelike TFFs can be determined by measuring the actual decay rate of A → ℓ + ℓ − B as a function of the dilepton invariant mass m ℓℓ = q, normalizing this dependence to the partial decay width Γ(A → Bγ), and then taking the ratio to the pure QED dependence for the decay rate of A → γ * B → ℓ + ℓ − B. Based on QED, the decay rate of η → γ * γ → ℓ + ℓ − γ can be parametrized as [10] dΓ(η → ℓ + ℓ − γ) dm ℓℓ Γ(η → γγ) = 4α 3πm ℓℓ ×
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: where F η is the TFF of the η meson and m η is the mass of the η meson.
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: Another feature of the A → γ * B → ℓ + ℓ − B decay amplitude is an angular anisotropy of the virtual photon decaying into a lepton pair, which also determines the density of events along m 2 (Bℓ) of the A → ℓ + ℓ − B Dalitz plot.
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: For the ℓ + , ℓ − , and B in the rest frame of A, the angle θ * between the direction of one of the leptons in the virtual-photon (or the dilepton) rest frame and the direction of the dilepton system (which is opposite to the direction of B) follows the dependence [12]:
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: with the sin 2 θ * term becoming very small when m ℓℓ >> 2m ℓ .
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: The decay rate of ω → π 0 γ * → π 0 ℓ + ℓ − can be parametrized as [10] dΓ(ω → π 0 ℓ + ℓ − ) dm ℓℓ Γ(ω → π 0 γ)
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: where F ωπ 0 is the ω → π 0 γ * TFF, and m ω and m π 0 are the masses of the ω and π 0 mesons, respectively.
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: The angular dependence of the virtual photon decaying into a lepton pair for ω → π 0 γ * → π 0 ℓ + ℓ − is the same as Eq.
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays
A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: Note that the [QED(m ℓℓ )] terms in Eqs.
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: (1) and (3) and the angular dependence in Eq.
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: (2) represent only the leading-order term of the decay amplitudes, and, in principle, radiative corrections need to be considered for a more accurate calculation of [QED(m ℓℓ , cos θ * )].
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: Taking those corrections into account is vital for measuring the Dalitz decay π 0 → e + e − γ, where the magnitude of the corrections at the largest q is even larger than the expected TFF contribution.
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: The most recent calculations of radiative corrections to the differential decay rate of the Dalitz decay π 0 → e + e − γ were reported by the Prague group in Ref.
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays
A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: The authors of that work also mentioned that radiative corrections for η → e + e − γ could be evaluated by replacing the π 0 mass with the η mass in their code.
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: More precise calculations for η → e + e − γ by the Prague group are still in progress.
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: Typically, taking radiative corrections into account makes the angular dependence of the virtualphoton decay weaker.
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: The corrected [QED η ] term integrated over cos θ * is ∼1.5% larger than the leading-order term at low q and becomes ∼10% lower at q = 455 MeV.
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: The magnitude of radiative corrections for [QED ωπ 0 ] is expected to be of the same order.
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: From the VMD assumption, TFFs are usually parametrized in a pole approximation
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: where Λ is the effective mass of the virtual vector meson, and the parameter Λ −2 reflects the TFF slope at m ℓℓ = 0.
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: A simple VMD model would incorporate only the ρ, ω, and φ resonances (in the narrow-width approximation) as virtual vector mesons driving the photon interaction in A → γ * B. Using a quark model for the corresponding couplings would yield the TFF slope Λ −2 η = 1.80 GeV −2 and Λ −2 ωπ 0 = 1.68 GeV −2 [10], corresponding to Λ η = 745 MeV and Λ ωπ 0 = 772 MeV.
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: The nearness of Λ ωπ 0 to the ρ mass comes from isospin conservation in the ω → π 0 γ * → π 0 ℓ + ℓ − decay, allowing only γ * → ℓ + ℓ − with I = 1, which eliminates contributions from ω and φ with I = 0.
body_text.section: A. Amplitudes for Dalitz decays

body_text.text: B. Dalitz decays of η
From the experimental and phenomenological point of view, the η → γ * γ → ℓ + ℓ − γ TFF is currently the one investigated most.
body_text.section: B. Dalitz decays of η

body_text.text: The early measurement of the η slope parameter by Lepton-G [14], Λ −2 η = (1.90±0.40 tot ) GeV −2 , was based on quite limited statistics.
body_text.section: B. Dalitz decays of η

body_text.text: The first results from the NA60 Collaboration [15], Λ −2 η = (1.95 ± 0.17 stat ± 0.05 syst ) GeV −2 , was based on 2.6 • 10 4 µ + µ − pairs detected in peripheral In-In data, 9 • 10 3 of which were identified to be from η → µ + µ − γ decays.
body_text.section: B. Dalitz decays of η

body_text.text: The latest experiment by the NA60 Collaboration with p-A collisions [12], which increased the statistics of muon pairs by one order of magnitute, reported Λ −2 η = (1.934 ± 0.067 stat ± 0.050 syst ) GeV −2 , improving significantly the accuracy, compared to the earlier result.
body_text.section: B. Dalitz decays of η

body_text.text: The first measurement by the A2 Collaboration at MAMI, Λ −2 η = (1.92 ± 0.35 stat ± 0.13 syst ) GeV −2 , was based on an analysis of 1.35 • 10 3 η → e + e − γ decays [16].
body_text.section: B. Dalitz decays of η

body_text.text: Later on, a higher-accuracy result, Λ −2 η = (1.95 ± 0.15 stat ± 0.10 syst ) GeV −2 , obtained by the A2 Collaboration, was based on an analysis of 2.2 • 10 4 η → e + e − γ decays from a total of 3 • 10 7 η mesons produced in the γp → ηp reaction [17].
body_text.section: B. Dalitz decays of η

body_text.text: In that work, there is also a detailed discussion of agreement between the experimental data and recent calculations available for the η TFF at the moment.
body_text.section: B. Dalitz decays of η

body_text.text: Combining those A2 results with available experimental data in the spacelike (the energy transfer less than the momentum transfer) region allowed the Mainz theoretical group to extract the slope parameter with the smallest uncertainty, Λ −2 η = (1.919±0.039) GeV − 2 [18].
body_text.section: B. Dalitz decays of η

body_text.text: Such synergy between theory and experiment allowed a data-driven calculation of the η → ℓ + ℓ − rare decay [8] and the reduction of the uncertainty in the pseudoscalar-exchange HLbL contribution to (g − 2) µ [19].
body_text.section: B. Dalitz decays of η

body_text.text: The most recent η → γ * γ calculation with the updated dispersive analysis by the Jülich group was presented in Ref.
body_text.section: B. Dalitz decays of η

body_text.text: [20], demonstrating even better agreement with the data, compared to the previous calculations by this group in Ref.
body_text.section: B. Dalitz decays of η
B. Dalitz decays of η

body_text.text: The improvement was based on including the a 2 -meson contribution in the dispersive analysis of the radiative decay η → π + π − γ [22], which is connected to the isovector contributions of the η → γγ * TFF.
body_text.section: B. Dalitz decays of η

body_text.text: This resulted in a better control of F ηγ * γ calculations and a better consistency of these calculations with those for F η ′ γ * γ .
body_text.section: B. Dalitz decays of η

body_text.text: Also in Ref.
body_text.section: B. Dalitz decays of η

body_text.text: [20], a better consistency was reached between the single off-shell form factor F ηγ * γ and the double off-shell form factor F ηγ * γ * , an accurate model-independent determination of which would be an important step towards a reliable evaluation of the HLbL scattering contribution to (g − 2) µ .
body_text.section: B. Dalitz decays of η

body_text.text: C. Dalitz decays of ω
The situation is quite different for the ω → π 0 γ * → π 0 ℓ + ℓ − decay.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: The experimental data are available only for the ω → π 0 µ + µ − decay, showing fair consistency with each other.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: However, the existing theoretical approaches, which successfully reproduce most recent TFF data available for η and other light mesons in different momentumtransfer regions, cannot describe the TFF data based on the ω → π 0 γ * → π 0 µ + µ − decay at large m(µ + µ − ).
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: The pioneering measurement of ω → π 0 µ + µ − , Λ −2 ωπ 0 = (2.36 ± 0.21 tot ) GeV −2 , by Lepton-G [23], made a few decades ago, was based on 60 ± 9 observed events.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: The level of background events, which comprised 11% from nonresonant sources and 3% from the ω → π 0 π + π − decay (with charged pions decaying into muons) and the ρ → π 0 µ + µ − decay, could be significant at high m(µ + µ − ), where the theoretical predictions were not able to describe the Lepton-G data.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: Most recent measurements by the NA60 experiment in peripheral In-In data [15], Λ −2 ωπ 0 = (2.24 ± 0.06 stat ± 0.02 syst ) GeV −2 from 3 • 10 3 ω → π 0 µ + µ − decays, and in p-A collisions [12], Λ −2 ωπ 0 = (2.223 ± 0.026 stat ± 0.037 syst ) GeV −2 , were based on measuring the entire spectrum of the µ + µ − invariant masses, without detecting any neutral finalstate particles.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: All contributions, except η → µ + µ − γ, ω → π 0 µ + µ − , and ρ → µ + µ − , were subtracted from this spectrum.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: The acceptance-corrected spectrum was then fitted with these three contributions.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: According to a more scrupulous analysis of p-A collisions, involving also much higher statistics than peripheral In-In data, all possible systematic uncertainties were very carefully taken into account.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: Though these latest |F ωπ 0 | 2 results were slightly lower than from peripheral In-In data, they confirmed once again the discrepancy with the available predictions in the vicinity of the kinematic limit.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: In Refs.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: [24,25], the calculations of the ωπ 0 TFF were based on a chiral Lagrangian approach; this included light vector mesons and Goldstone bosons to calculate the decays of light vector mesons into a pseudoscalar meson and a dilepton in leading order.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: Recent calculations based on dispersion theory were presented in Refs.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω
C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: In Ref.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: [26], these calculations and their theoretical uncertainties relied on a previous dispersive analysis [28] of the corresponding three-pion decays and the pion vector form factor.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: In Ref.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: [27], a similar dispersive analysis is performed for the same three-pion decays (ω/φ → π + π − π 0 ) with an additional parametrization of the inelastic contributions by a power series in a suitably chosen conformal variable that took into account the change in the analytical behavior of the amplitude.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: As a further application of this formalism, the e/m TFFs of ω/φ → π 0 γ * were also computed.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: Motivated by the discrepancies between the theoretical calculations of the ωπ 0 TFF and the experimental data, a further investigation of this form factor was made by using analyticity and unitarity in a framework known as the method of unitarity bounds [29].
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: The results for the upper and lower bounds on |F ωπ 0 | 2 in the elastic region provided a significant check on those obtained with standard dispersion relations, confirming the existence of a disagreement with experimental data in the q region around 0.6 GeV.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: Other tests of the consistency of the ωπ 0 TFF with unitarity and analyticity were recently reported in Ref.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω
C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: A dispersive analysis of the ωπ 0 e/m TFF described in this work used as input the discontinuity provided by unitarity below the ωπ 0 threshold and, for the first time, included experimental data on the modulus measured from e + e − → ωπ 0 at higher energies.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: That analysis also confirmed the discrepancy between the experimental data and the theoretical calculation of the ωπ 0 TFF in this q region.
body_text.section: C. Dalitz decays of ω

body_text.text: D. Dalitz decays with A2

Compared to the ω → π 0 µ + µ − decay, the advantage of measuring ω → π 0 e + e − would be in giving access to the TFF energy dependence at low momentum transfer, which is important for data-driven approaches calculating the corresponding rare decays and the HLbL contribution to (g − 2) µ .
body_text.section: D. Dalitz decays with A2

body_text.text: The capability of the A2 experimental setup to measure Dalitz decays was demonstrated in Refs.
body_text.section: D. Dalitz decays with A2
D. Dalitz decays with A2

body_text.text: Measuring ω → π 0 e + e − with the A2 setup is more challenging because of a much smaller signal, compared to background contributions.
body_text.section: D. Dalitz decays with A2

body_text.text: Nonresonant contributions, like π 0 π 0 and π 0 η final states can cause the same number of electromagnetic showers as the π 0 e + e − final state.
body_text.section: D. Dalitz decays with A2

body_text.text: Also, both π 0 and η have their own e + e − γ decay modes, resulting in e + e − pairs that can be detected along with π 0 , if the photon from the former decay is not detected.
body_text.section: D. Dalitz decays with A2

body_text.text: The ω → π 0 π + π − decay, which has a branching ratio one order of magnitude larger than that for ω → π 0 γ, can mimic the π 0 e + e − final state when both charged pions deposit their total energy due to nuclear interactions in an electromagnetic calorimeter.
body_text.section: D. Dalitz decays with A2

body_text.text: Because of the smallness of the η → π + π − γ branching ratio, such a problem does not exist for the η → e + e − γ decay.
body_text.section: D. Dalitz decays with A2

body_text.text: Another decay, η → π + π − π 0 , with a larger branching ratio, cannot mimic an η → e + e − γ peak with one finalstate photon being undetected.
body_text.section: D. Dalitz decays with A2

body_text.text: Thus, the background situation requires a more sophisticated analysis for measuring ω → π 0 e + e − than is needed for η → e + e − γ.
body_text.section: D. Dalitz decays with A2

body_text.text: To improve the statistical accuracy, two sets of A2 data from 2007 and 2009 were analyzed independently, and their results were combined together.
body_text.section: D. Dalitz decays with A2

body_text.text: The same technique was tested with η → e + e − γ events, which have much better statistics and less background, in order to determine the effect on the systematic uncertainty caused by this more sophisticated analysis.
body_text.section: D. Dalitz decays with A2

body_text.text: Including 2009 data in the present analysis doubled the η → e + e − γ statistics, compared to the previous analysis of only 2007 data [17], and, along with other improvements, resulted in a better accuracy of the A2 results for this Dalitz decay.
body_text.section: D. Dalitz decays with A2

body_text.text: The new results for the η and ωπ 0 e/m TFFs presented in this paper are based on measuring η → e + e − γ and ω → π 0 e + e − decays from a total of 5.87 • 10 7 η mesons and 2.27 • 10 7 ω mesons produced in the γp → ηp and γp → ωp reactions, respectively.
body_text.section: D. Dalitz decays with A2

body_text.text: Previously, the same data sets were used, for instance, in a measurement of the η → π 0 γγ decay [31].
body_text.section: D. Dalitz decays with A2

body_text.text: In addition to the increase in the experimental statistics, compared to the previous η → e + e − γ measurements [16,17] by the A2 Collaboration, the present TFF results include systematic uncertainties in every individual data point.
body_text.section: D. Dalitz decays with A2

body_text.text: This allows a more fair comparison of the data with theoretical calculations, especially those calculations which do not follow the VMD pole approximation, typically used to fit the data in experimental analyses.
body_text.section: D. Dalitz decays with A2

body_text.text: Data-driven approaches would also prefer data points with total uncertainties, rather than measurements with the systematic uncertainties given only for the slope-parameter values.
body_text.section: D. Dalitz decays with A2

body_text.text: As in the case of the previous measurements, radiative corrections to the QED differential decay rate of the η and ω Dalitz decays were not taken into account in the present work because their precise magnitude had not been calculated, but possible systematic uncertainties due to those corrections are discussed further in the text.
body_text.section: D. Dalitz decays with A2

body_text.text: II.
EXPERIMENTAL SETUP
The processes γp → ηp → e + e − γp and γp → ωp → π 0 e + e − p were measured by using the Crystal Ball (CB) [32] as a central calorimeter and TAPS [33,34] as a forward calorimeter.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: These detectors were installed in the energy-tagged bremsstrahlung photon beam of the Mainz Microtron (MAMI) [35,36].
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: The photon energies were determined by using the Glasgow-Mainz tagging spectrometer [37][38][39].
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: The CB detector is a sphere consisting of 672 optically isolated NaI(Tl) crystals, shaped as truncated triangular pyramids, which point toward the center of the sphere.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: The crystals are arranged in two hemispheres that cover 93% of 4π, sitting outside a central spherical cavity with a radius of 25 cm, which holds the target and inner detectors.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: In this experiment, TAPS was arranged in a plane consisting of 384 BaF 2 counters of hexagonal cross section.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: It was installed 1.5 m downstream of the CB center and covered the full azimuthal range for polar angles from 1 • to 20 • .
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: More details on the energy and angular resolution of the CB and TAPS are given in Refs.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP
II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: The present measurement used electron beams with energies 1508 and 1557 MeV from the Mainz Microtron, MAMI-C [36].
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: The data with the 1508-MeV beam were taken in 2007 (Run-I) and those with the 1557-MeV beam in 2009 (Run-II).
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: Bremsstrahlung photons, produced by the beam electrons in a 10-µm Cu radiator and collimated by a 4-mm-diameter Pb collimator, were incident on a liquid hydrogen (LH 2 ) target located in the center of the CB.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: The LH 2 target was 5-cm and 10-cm long in Run-I and Run-II, respectively.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: The total amount of material around the LH 2 target, including the Kapton cell and the 1-mm-thick carbon-fiber beamline, was equivalent to 0.8% of a radiation length X 0 .
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: In the present measurement, it was essential to keep the material budget as low as possible to minimize the background from η → γγ and ω → π 0 γ decays with conversion of the photons into e + e − pairs.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: The target was surrounded by a Particle IDentification (PID) detector [43] used to distinguish between charged and neutral particles.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: It is made of 24 scintillator bars (50 cm long, 4 mm thick) arranged as a cylinder with a radius of 12 cm.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: A general sketch of the CB, TAPS, and PID is shown in Fig. 1.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: A multi-wire proportional chamber, MWPC, also shown in this figure (which consists of two cylindrical MWPCs inside each other), was not installed during Run-I and was not used during Run-II as it could not operate in the high photon flux used in this experiment.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: In Run-I, the energies of the incident photons were analyzed up to 1402 MeV by detecting the postbremsstrahlung electrons in the Glasgow tagged-photon spectrometer (Glasgow tagger) [37][38][39], and up to 1448 MeV in Run-II.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: The uncertainty in the energy of the tagged photons is mainly determined by the segmentation of the tagger focal-plane detector in combination with the energy of the MAMI electron beam used in the experiments.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: Increasing the MAMI energy increases the energy range covered by the spectrometer and also has the corresponding effect on the uncertainty in E γ .
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: For both the MAMI energy settings of 1508 and 1557 MeV, this uncertainty was about ±2 MeV.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: More details on the tagger energy calibration and uncertainties in the ener-gies can be found in Ref.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP
II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: The experimental trigger in Run-I required the total energy deposited in the CB to exceed ∼320 MeV and the number of so-called hardware clusters in the CB (multiplicity trigger) to be two or more.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: In the trigger, a hardware cluster in the CB was a block of 16 adjacent crystals in which at least one crystal had an energy deposit larger than 30 MeV.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: Depending on the data-taking period, events with a cluster multiplicity of two were prescaled with different rates.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: TAPS was not included in the multiplicity trigger for these experiments.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: In Run-II, the trigger on the total energy in the CB was increased to ∼340 MeV, and the multiplicity trigger required ≥ 3 hardware clusters in the CB.
body_text.section: II. EXPERIMENTAL SETUP

body_text.text: III.
DATA HANDLING A. Selection of candidate events

body_text.text: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

The PID detector was used to identify the final-state e + e − pair (the detection efficiency for e +/− in the PID is close to 100%) in the events initially selected as γp → 3γp and γp → 4γp candidates.
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: The γp → π 0 γγp → 4γp hypothesis was needed for selecting only γp → π 0 e + e − p candidates from the five-cluster events.
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: Because, with respect to the LH 2 target, the PID provides a full coverage only for the CB crystals, events with at least three e/m showers in the CB were selected for further analysis, allowing one e/m shower to be detected in TAPS for γp → π 0 e + e − p candidates, and requiring the electron and positron to be detected in the CB.
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: Requiring at least three e/m showers in the CB also made almost all selected events pass the trigger requirements on both the total energy and the multiplicity.
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: The identification of e +/− in the CB was based on a correlation between the φ angles of fired PID elements with the angles of e/m showers in the calorimeter.
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: The MC simulations of γp → ηp → e + e − γp and γp → ωp → π 0 e + e − p → γγe + e − p were used to optimize this procedure, minimizing a probability of misidentification of e +/− with the final-state photons.
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: This procedure is optimized with respect to how close the φ angle of an e/m shower in the CB should be to the correspodning angle of a fired PID element to be considered as e +/− , and how far it should be to be considered as a photon.
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: This decreases the efficiency in selecting true events for which the φ angle of the electron or the positron is close to the photon φ angle.
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: The analysis of the MC simulations of possible background reactions for η → e + e − γ revealed that only the process γp → ηp → γγp could mimic η → e + e − γ events.
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: This occurs mostly when one of the final-state photons converts into an e + e − pair in the material between the production vertex and the NaI(Tl) surface.
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: Because the opening angle between such electrons and positrons is typically very small, this background can be significantly suppressed by requiring that e + and e − were identified by different PID elements.
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: However, such a requirement also decreases the detection efficiency for actual η → e + e − γ events, especially at low invariant masses m(e + e − ).
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: In further analysis of η → e + e − γ events, both the options, with larger and smaller background remaining from η → γγ, were tested.

body_text.text: Similarly, the process γp → ωp → π 0 γp → 3γp can mimic ω → π 0 e + e − events via converting a final-state photon into an e + e − pair.
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: Another source of actual ω → γγe + e − events comes from ω → π 0 γ decays with the Dalitz decay of π 0 .
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: Because of the QED dependence of this decay, it dominates at low masses m(e + e − ) and can be suppressed by requiring that e + and e − were identified by different PID elements.
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: Further reduction of this background can be achieved by requiring the two finalstate photons to be from the π 0 decay.
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: Other background sources that should be significantly suppressed in the analysis of ω → π 0 e + e − events are the processes γp → π 0 π 0 p and γp → π 0 ηp, with the η meson decaying into two photons or into e + e − γ.
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: In the case of the two photon decay, both the photons can convert before or inside the PID, mimicking an e + e − pair.
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: In the case of the e + e − γ decay, e + e − pairs with very low invariant masses often hit the same PID element and are reconstructed as one cluster in the CB.
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: If the photon from the same decay converts before or inside the PID, such an event could be identified as a π 0 e + e − final state.
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: Similarly, the process γp → π 0 π 0 p can mimic γp → π 0 e + e − p events.
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: Without suppressing background from γp → π 0 π 0 p and γp → π 0 ηp, the signal from ω → π 0 e + e − would be comparable with the statistical fluctuations of the background events, preventing the measurement of the TFF at m(e + e − ) close to the π 0 and η masses, with the η-mass region being especially important for the ωπ 0 TFF.
body_text.section: C. Identifying e + e − pairs and suppressing backgrounds

body_text.text: The suppression of background from γp → π 0 π 0 p and γp → π 0 ηp was based on the analysis of energy losses, dE/dx, in the PID elements.

body_text.text: According to the MC simulations of these backgrounds, many photons produce energy losses that are significantly smaller than dE/dx from a single e +/− , and the e + e − pairs reconstructed as one cluster in the CB result in a double-magnitude PID signal, compared to a single e +/− .

body_text.text: To reflect the actual differential energy deposit dE/dx in the PID, the energy signal from each element, ascribed to either e + or e − , was multiplied by the sine of the polar angle of the corresponding particle, the magnitude of which is taken from the kinematic-fit output.

body_text.section: C. comparison of ω results with other data and calculations

body_text.text: More measurements of the ω → π 0 e + e − decay, with much better statistical accuracy, especially at large m(ℓ + ℓ − ) masses, are needed to solve the problem of the inconsistency remaining between the calculations and the experimental data.
body_text.section: C. comparison of ω results with other data and calculations

body_text.text: Once the agreement between the theory and the experiment is established for the ω → π 0 γ * TFF, or the origin of the potential disagreement is understood, then such data could make an improvement in the theoretical uncertainties, in particular the dispersive model-independent calculations and the Padé-approximants method, which could then result in a better determination of the corresponding HLbL contribution to (g − 2) µ .
body_text.section: C. comparison of ω results with other data and calculations

body_text.text: V. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS
The Dalitz decays η → e + e − γ and ω → π 0 e + e − have been measured in the γp → ηp and γp → ωp reactions, respectively, with the A2 tagged-photon facility at the Mainz Microtron, MAMI.
body_text.section: V. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: The value obtained for the slope parameter of the η e/m TFF, Λ −2 η = (1.97 ± 0.11 tot ) GeV −2 , is in good agreement with previous measurements of the η → e + e − γ and η → µ + µ − γ decays, and the |F η | 2 results are in good agreement with recent theoretical calculations.
body_text.section: V. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: The uncertainty obtained in the value of Λ −2 η is lower than in previous results based on the η → e + e − γ decay and the NA60 result based on η → µ + µ − γ decays from peripheral In-In collisions.
body_text.section: V. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: The value obtained for ω, Λ −2 ωπ 0 = (1.99 ± 0.21 tot ) GeV −2 , is somewhat lower than previous measurements based on the ω → π 0 µ + µ − decay.
body_text.section: V. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: The results of this work for |F ωπ 0 | 2 are in better agreement with theoretical calculations than the data from earlier experiments.
body_text.section: V. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: However, the statistical accuracy of the present data points at large m(e + e − ) masses does not allow a final conclusion to be drawn about the energy dependence in this region.
body_text.section: V. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: More measurements of the ω → π 0 e + e − decay, with much better statistical accuracy, especially at large m(e + e − ) masses, are needed to solve the problem in the inconsistency remaining between the calculations and the experimental data.
body_text.section: V. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS

body_text.text: Compared to the η → µ + µ − γ and ω → π 0 µ + µ − decays, measuring η → e + e − γ and ω → π 0 e + e − decays gives access to the TFF energy de-pendence at low momentum transfer, which is important for data-driven approaches calculating the corresponding rare decays and the HLbL contribution to (g − 2) µ .
body_text.section: V. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS

The solution without including the a2-meson contribution is shown by a red dotted line with an error band, and the solution involving the a2 contribution by a blue dashed line.
The pole-approximation fits (black solid lines) to the results of Run-I and Run-II are depicted in panels
(a) and
(b), respectively.
The fit parameter p0 reflects the general normalization of the data points, and p1 is the slope parameter Λ −2 [GeV −2 ].
For a better comparison of the magnitudes of total uncertainties from the two data sets, the error bars of Run-I are plotted in
(a) on the top of the error bars of Run-II, and the other way around in
nal peak with respect to the background level under it.
Typically, such a best fit gives the largest ratio between the corresponding dΓ/dm value and its uncertainty.

Because the fits for a given m(e + e − ) bin with different selection criteria or different background parametrizations were based on the same initial data sample, the corresponding dΓ/dm results were correlated and could not be considered as independent measurements for calculating the uncertainty in the averaged dΓ/dm value.
Thus, this uncertainty was taken from the best fit for the given m(e + e − ) bin, which was a conservative estimate of the uncertainty in the averaged dΓ/dm value.
The systematic uncertainty in this dΓ/dm value was taken as the root mean square of the results from all fits made for this bin.
The total uncertainty in this dΓ/dm value was calculated by adding in quadrature its fit (partially reflecting experimental statistics in the bin) and systematic uncertainties.

The overall statistics of 5.4 • 10 4 η → e + e − γ decays involved in all the fits provided quite small fit uncertainties, with the average magnitude of the systematic uncertainties being ∼35% of the fit uncertainties.

Because the overall statistics for ω → π 0 e + e − were only 1.1 • 10 3 decays, the total uncertainties were dominated by the fit uncertainties, with average magnitude of the systematic uncertainties being ∼20% of the fit uncertainties.

In the end, the dΓ/dm(e + e − ) results from Run-I and Run-II, which were independent measurements, were combined as a weighted average with weights taken as inverse values of their total uncertainties in quadrature.

The results for |F η (m e + e − )| 2 and |F ωπ 0 (m e + e − )| 2 were obtained by dividing the combined results for dΓ(η → e + e − γ)/dm(e + e − ) and dΓ(ω → π 0 e + e − )/dm(e + e − ) by the corresponding QED terms from Eqs.
(1) and 3, and using the η → γγ and ω → π 0 γ branching ratios from RPP [45].

To check the consistency of the individual TFF results obtained from Run-I and Run-II, the corresponding dΓ/dm(e + e − ) results were recalculated into |F η (m e + e − )| 2 and |F ωπ 0 (m e + e − )| 2 as well.
